review_title: Some thoughts from an IT professional
job_title: IT Support Analyst in Winston-Salem, NC
pros:
In my experience, Novant does well to thrive in the very complex and dynamic industry that healthcare is. They offer competitive wages for comparable jobs else where. I am pleased with the available benefits including good insurance, 5 weeks of PTO a year, tuition reimbursement and in most cases yearly market increases at 2.5 - 3%. 

While advancement paths can be challenging to locate they are their and obtainable. Novant is driven by patient care and they have grown to triple their employee base and footprint in the time that I've been employed here. They offer a challenging yet rewarding environment that has no shortage of work or complex problems that need to be addressed to maintain a high level of patient care.
cons:
All work places have stress! After reading through several other comments i'll try to stay away from the more trivial things that occur at any job. I can fairly say that i work with a lot of amazing and top notch people that  are eager to solve any problem, but also with some who are far from ideal as either an employee or IT representative.  All it takes is the change in legislation or health care reimbursement to send A large health care entity in a completely new direction to adjust and keep 30k people employed. 

Novant presents many stressful and urgent stressful situations in the interest of patient care which require immediate action from many teams,  including IT. I've observed several instances a large knowledge/Skill set gap between senior strategic leaders and the more tactical middle mangers which causes a lack in communication,  implementations being handled improperly, and unnecessary increased support for the lifetime of the product. Time management between projects, rounding, and trouble tickets can prove to be challenging with limited staff. Training is  almost exclusively all on the job and can also be slow due to limited staff and their busy daily workload. Interdepartmental communication for IT can be greatly improved although i'm sure it's difficult with such a large organization.

pros:
Novant Health has been a breath of fresh air for my work life balance. Healthcare is a demanding field but this organization understands that in order to take care of people, they have to take care of their people.  During my  first vacation, I was encouraged to completely unplug from email and focus on recharging. This is unheard of at many other organizations including my last one where it was required to check-in on mission-critical tasks. I was completely burned out so this was a needed change.  

I've never felt like a number and everyone's voice matters. Team members are encouraged to speak up when it comes to the remarkable patient experience and pause when they have concerns. I have seen team members suggest ideas or bring up concerns to the CEO and top executives at town hall style meetings and can see the positive impacts of those ideas as they come to fruition.     

I'm not only a team member but also a patient, and it's truly amazing to see the remarkable patient experience in action. Nurses, doctors, PA's, and front desk team members all treat me and my family with care and compassion.  

Novant Health has been an incredible fit for me personally and I recommend jobs to people I have worked with.  It continues to be an organization that I'm proud to come into work each day and make a difference!
cons: Projects can sometimes take a long time to implement. Novant Health moves pretty quickly for healthcare but just not fast enough as some other organizations. I have seen changes made to IT in the past year that show we are moving faster, and I hope that trend continues.

The backstabbing, gossip, humiliation and absolute cruelty that goes on between certain nurses is astounding. During my time I’ve heard disparaging comments about people’s intelligence, sexuality, weight (this is a frequent one), English speaking ability, marital status, child bearing status, socio-economic class, perceived ability (or lack thereof), laziness, clothing choice (and the “cheapness thereof”), amongst many others. And this is only what I’ve heard first hand. I’ve heard things have happened that I wish were completely unimaginable. When I attempted to address these comments with HR, and encourage HR to ask almost everyone else their own stories (as I was unwilling to repeat here-say and those stories were far more interesting than my own), I was told “it would be understandable if I had considered quitting”, and asked if I had considered changing departments. It became absolutely clear that they considered me to be the problem, not the people that abused their undeserved powers and harassed other staff. 

Everything this company does is JUST to cover its own behind. If you’re not willing to be a fall-man for anything bad that happens, don’t take a job here. If you’re not willing to be the center of harassment and ridicule if you refuse to take part in the cattiness and gossip that envelops this place, don’t take a job here. If you’re not willing to be completely ignored by most of management unless you suck up to them, don’t take a job here. If you’re not willing to have your schedule intentionally messed with when you bump heads with someone (and then have management ask what YOU could have done differently in that situation, ignoring the whole intentional-malicious-schedule-rearrangement), then don’t work here.
